title: Sudden Hearing Loss as an Initial Symptom of Multiple Sclerosis
chief_complaint: I experienced a sudden loss of hearing, a feeling of fullness, and a hissing sound in my left ear. I also had a single episode of severe dizziness and nausea.

problem_summary.course: Acute onset of auditory symptoms followed by a diagnosis of MS; 11 months later, systemic neurological symptoms worsened (weakness, numbness, gait disturbances).
problem_summary.associated_symptoms: Aural fullness, tinnitus ('hissing'), vertigo, nausea. Later: uncontrolled crying spells, decreased appetite, extremity weakness, facial numbness, gait and visual disturbances.
problem_summary.functional_impact: Significant hearing difficulty in the left ear; later progression to significant systemic neurological impairment.
problem_summary.goals_motivation: Diagnosis of the sudden hearing loss.

history.present_illness: The patient presented with complaints of sudden hearing loss, fullness, and tinnitus in the left ear, accompanied by a single episode of vertigo with nausea.
history.otologic_history: Initially, a cochlear etiology was strongly considered.
history.medical_psych_history: Subsequent to the audiological workup, the patient was diagnosed with Multiple Sclerosis (MS). 11 months post-diagnosis, she was hospitalized with worsening neurological symptoms including crying spells, weakness in all extremities, and numbness.
history.prior_management: Diagnostic audiological workup followed by radiologic consultation.
history.patient_goals: Identify the cause of sudden hearing loss.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.key_findings: Right ear thresholds are essentially normal. Left ear shows a moderate to severe sensorineural hearing loss.

numeric_results.LE_thresholds: Sloping loss: approx 40 dB HL at 250 Hz dropping to 60-70 dB HL in high frequencies

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.key_findings: Excellent recognition in the right ear; reduced but relatively good recognition in the left ear given the degree of loss.

tests.name: Auditory Brainstem Response (ABR)
tests.key_findings: Right ear normal. Left ear showed poorly defined morphology with delayed Wave I and Wave V. The I-V interwave interval was abnormal, suggesting central involvement.

numeric_results.RE_morphology: Good, Waves I-V present at normal latencies
numeric_results.LE_morphology: Poorly defined at 80 and 90 dB nHL

tests.name: MRI
tests.key_findings: Large plaque located at the lateral pons on the left side of the brainstem. Likely compromised the left dorsal cochlear nucleus.

overall_audiologic_summary: The patient presents with a left moderate-to-severe sensorineural hearing loss. While the delayed Wave I on ABR might suggest a cochlear component, the disproportionate delay of Wave V and the abnormal I-V interwave interval indicate retrocochlear/central pathology. MRI confirmed a large MS plaque on the left lateral pons affecting the dorsal cochlear nucleus. This case illustrates that sudden hearing loss can be a rare initial symptom of Multiple Sclerosis.
counseling_points: Explain that the hearing loss and 'hissing' sounds are related to the lesion found on the brainstem (pons) affecting the hearing nerve pathway.
Discuss that while sudden hearing loss is often cochlear, the specific timing tests (ABR) indicated a problem further up the pathway, which the MRI confirmed.
Coordinate care with neurology for the management of Multiple Sclerosis, as the hearing loss is a symptom of the broader neurological condition.
notes_for_actor: Portray a patient who is initially confused by the sudden hearing loss and vertigo, thinking it might be an ear infection.
In the follow-up context (11 months later), demonstrate significant distress due to the progression of symptoms (crying spells, weakness, numbness).
The 'hissing' tinnitus is a specific descriptor to use.
